source_text:
"Tell me about your dream house," Hollis said, smiling.

"Okay," I said, slowly. This was something I didn't talk about too often. "It will have to be off the beaten road, of course. I want it to look like a log cabin, but without the inconveniences of a real log cabin. I found a plan on the Internet, and I bought it. But of course, I want to alter it a little."

"Of course," he said, taking a sip of beer. "

It would be two bedrooms and a study, with a family room. There'd be a kitchen here, with the washroom right off of it." I was looking down at the table, drawing with my finger. "Around back, there'd be a *porte cochere* for the cars, so you could carry groceries right into the kitchen without getting wet. There's a deck off the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'd put it off the family room. That's where the fireplace will be, and you could keep your firewood on the deck. And you could put your gas grill on the deck. For steaks."
translation_attempt:
"Ceritakan padaku tentang rumah impianmu," kata Hollis sambil tersenyum.

"Baiklah," jawabku, perlahan. Ini adalah sesuatu yang jarang sekali aku bicarakan. "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari keramaian. Aku ingin tampilannya seperti kabin kayu, tapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan kabin kayu yang sebenarnya. Aku menemukan rancangannya di internet, dan aku membelinya. Tapi tentu saja, aku ingin mengubahnya sedikit."

"Tentu," katanya sambil meneguk bir.

Rumah itu akan memiliki dua kamar tidur dan ruang kerja, dengan ruang keluarga. Akan ada dapur di sini, dengan kamar mandi tepat di sampingnya. Aku menunduk melihat meja, menggambar dengan jariku. "Di bagian belakang, akan ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa membawa belanjaan langsung ke dapur tanpa basah. Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di samping ruang keluarga. Di sanalah perapian akan berada, dan kamu bisa menyimpan kayu bakar di teras. Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak."
feedback:
--- ANALYSIS ---
The source text is a casual conversation snippet from a novel. The tone is relaxed and conversational. The style is straightforward and descriptive, with a focus on conveying details about the dream house. The meaning is clear and easy to follow, detailing the features of the house the speaker envisions. The use of colloquialisms ("off the beaten road") and informal sentence structure contribute to the natural flow of the dialogue.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally accurate but suffers from some awkward phrasing and unnatural sentence structures in Indonesian. While the core meaning is preserved, the translation doesn't flow as smoothly as it could.

Here's a breakdown of specific issues:

1. "jauh dari keramaian" - While technically correct, "off the beaten road" implies seclusion and remoteness. "jauh dari keramaian" simply means "far from the crowd," which is not the same nuance. Consider "terpencil" (remote) or "di lokasi yang tersembunyi" (in a hidden location).
2. "tampilanannya seperti kabin kayu" - This is a bit literal. "Looks like a log cabin" can be better rendered as "berbentuk seperti kabin kayu" (shaped like a log cabin) or "mirip kabin kayu" (resembling a log cabin).
3. "ketidaknyamanan kabin kayu yang sebenarnya" - This phrase is clunky and doesn't quite capture the intended meaning. It could be rephrased as "kekurangan kabin kayu yang sebenarnya" (the actual drawbacks of a log cabin) or "tidak praktis seperti kabin kayu sungguhan" (not as practical as a real log cabin).
4. "tepat di sampingnya" - This is grammatically correct but slightly formal. "di sebelah" (next to) might sound more natural in casual conversation.
5. "Di sanalah perapian akan berada" - This is redundant. "Di sanalah perapiannya" (The fireplace will be there) is more concise and natural.
6. "Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak." - The sentence is a bit abrupt. A more natural phrasing would be: "Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras untuk memanggang steak." (And you can put a gas grill on the deck for grilling steaks.) or "Kamu juga bisa memanggang steak di teras dengan pemanggang gas." (You can also grill steaks on the deck with a gas grill.)

--- VERDICT ---
needs_revision
The translation needs revision to improve the flow and naturalness of the Indonesian. The use of more idiomatic expressions and a slightly less literal approach to certain phrases will enhance the overall quality and better reflect the original text's tone and style. Specific improvements are detailed in the evaluation section.

A previous translation attempt was evaluated and requires a complete rewrite. Your task is to deeply consider the editor's feedback and generate a completely new version of the translation that addresses the identified problems.

Start again from scratch, keeping the feedback in mind.

--- CONTEXT ---
Text type: fictional text, novel excerpt
Source Language: English
Target Language: Indonesian

--- SOURCE TEXT ---
"Tell me about your dream house," Hollis said, smiling.

"Okay," I said, slowly. This was something I didn't talk about too often. "It will have to be off the beaten road, of course. I want it to look like a log cabin, but without the inconveniences of a real log cabin. I found a plan on the Internet, and I bought it. But of course, I want to alter it a little."

"Of course," he said, taking a sip of beer. "

It would be two bedrooms and a study, with a family room. There'd be a kitchen here, with the washroom right off of it." I was looking down at the table, drawing with my finger. "Around back, there'd be a *porte cochere* for the cars, so you could carry groceries right into the kitchen without getting wet. There's a deck off the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'd put it off the family room. That's where the fireplace will be, and you could keep your firewood on the deck. And you could put your gas grill on the deck. For steaks."

--- EDITOR'S FEEDBACK ---
--- ANALYSIS ---
The source text is a casual conversation snippet from a novel. The tone is relaxed and conversational. The style is straightforward and descriptive, with a focus on conveying details about the dream house. The meaning is clear and easy to follow, detailing the features of the house the speaker envisions. The use of colloquialisms ("off the beaten road") and informal sentence structure contribute to the natural flow of the dialogue.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally accurate but suffers from some awkward phrasing and unnatural sentence structures in Indonesian. While the core meaning is preserved, the translation doesn't flow as smoothly as it could.

Here's a breakdown of specific issues:

1. "jauh dari keramaian" - While technically correct, "off the beaten road" implies seclusion and remoteness. "jauh dari keramaian" simply means "far from the crowd," which is not the same nuance. Consider "terpencil" (remote) or "di lokasi yang tersembunyi" (in a hidden location).
2. "tampilanannya seperti kabin kayu" - This is a bit literal. "Looks like a log cabin" can be better rendered as "berbentuk seperti kabin kayu" (shaped like a log cabin) or "mirip kabin kayu" (resembling a log cabin).
3. "ketidaknyamanan kabin kayu yang sebenarnya" - This phrase is clunky and doesn't quite capture the intended meaning. It could be rephrased as "kekurangan kabin kayu yang sebenarnya" (the actual drawbacks of a log cabin) or "tidak praktis seperti kabin kayu sungguhan" (not as practical as a real log cabin).
4. "tepat di sampingnya" - This is grammatically correct but slightly formal. "di sebelah" (next to) might sound more natural in casual conversation.
5. "Di sanalah perapian akan berada" - This is redundant. "Di sanalah perapiannya" (The fireplace will be there) is more concise and natural.
6. "Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak." - The sentence is a bit abrupt. A more natural phrasing would be: "Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras untuk memanggang steak." (And you can put a gas grill on the deck for grilling steaks.) or "Kamu juga bisa memanggang steak di teras dengan pemanggang gas." (You can also grill steaks on the deck with a gas grill.)

--- VERDICT ---
needs_revision
The translation needs revision to improve the flow and naturalness of the Indonesian. The use of more idiomatic expressions and a slightly less literal approach to certain phrases will enhance the overall quality and better reflect the original text's tone and style. Specific improvements are detailed in the evaluation section.

--- FINAL TASK ---
Generate a new, final, and improved translation in Indonesian:

feedback:
--- ANALYSIS ---
The source text uses informal language and a slightly cynical tone. The narrator is clearly skeptical and uses colloquialisms ("off the beaten road"). The style is direct and conversational, reflecting an internal monologue. The meaning is straightforward: the narrator is responding to a question about a dream house with a somewhat sarcastic and dismissive answer.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally accurate but lacks the punch and informality of the original. The phrase "Tentu saja" is repeated, which feels unnatural in Indonesian. While "jauh dari keramaian" translates "off the beaten road," it lacks the evocative quality. The use of "sambil meneguk bir" is a good attempt to convey the casual atmosphere, but could be improved. The overall flow is a bit stiff and lacks the natural rhythm of a conversation. Some phrases, like "dengan washroom tepat di sampingnya," are grammatically correct but sound overly formal.

--- VERDICT ---
needs_revision

The translation needs improvement to better capture the informal and slightly cynical tone of the original. Here's a breakdown of specific areas for improvement:

1. "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari keramaian." could be improved to "Tentu saja, rumah impianku harus jauh dari hiruk pikuk kota." (Of course, my dream house must be far from the hustle and bustle of the city.) This adds a bit more personality and emphasizes the narrator's perspective. Alternatively, "Harus jauh dari keramaian, tentu saja." (It must be far from the crowds, of course.) would sound more natural.

2. The repetition of "Tentu saja" is jarring. Consider replacing it with alternatives like "Ya," "Tentu," or even omitting it entirely where the meaning is clear. For example: "It will have to be off the beaten road... Ya."

3. "Aku ingin tampilannya seperti kabin kayu, tapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan kabin kayu yang sebenarnya."  This is a bit clunky. Try: "Aku ingin rumahnya terlihat seperti kabin kayu, tapi tanpa semua masalah yang biasanya ada di kabin kayu." (I want the house to look like a log cabin, but without all the problems that usually come with log cabins.)

4. "Di bagian belakang, akan ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa membawa belanjaan langsung ke dapur tanpa basah." sounds overly formal.  A better option is: "Di belakang, ada *porte cochere* buat mobil, jadi kamu bisa langsung bawa belanjaan ke dapur tanpa kena hujan." (In the back, there's a porte cochere for the car, so you can bring your groceries directly to the kitchen without getting wet.)

5. "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di samping ruang keluarga." The phrasing is awkward. Try: "Ada teras di sebelah kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan letakkan di samping ruang keluarga." (There's a terrace on the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'll put it next to the living room.)

6. "Di sanalah perapian akan berada, dan kamu bisa menyimpan kayu bakar di teras. Dan kamu bisa meletakkan panggangan gas di teras. Untuk steak." This is grammatically correct but sounds unnatural. Consider: "Di sana ada perapian, dan kayu bakar bisa disimpan di teras. Panggangan gas juga bisa ditaruh di sana, buat memanggang steak." (There's a fireplace there, and you can store firewood on the terrace. You can also put the gas grill there, for grilling steaks.)

1. "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari keramaian." could be improved to "Tentu saja, rumah impianku harus jauh dari hiruk pikuk kota." Alternatively, "Harus jauh dari keramaian, tentu saja." (It must be far from the crowds, of course.) would sound more natural.

4. "Di bagian belakang, akan ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa membawa belanjaan langsung ke dapur tanpa basah." sounds overly formal.  A better option is: "Di belakang, ada *porte cochere* buat mobil, jadi kamu bisa langsung bawa belanjaan ke dapur tanpa kena hujan." (In the back, there's a porte cochere for the car, so you can bring your groceries directly to the kitchen without getting wet.)

5. "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di samping ruang keluarga." The phrasing is awkward. Try: "Ada teras di sebelah kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan letakkan di samping ruang keluarga." (There's a terrace on the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'll put it next to the living room.)

6. "Di sanalah perapian akan berada, dan kamu bisa menyimpan kayu bakar di teras. Dan kamu bisa meletakkan panggangan gas di teras. Untuk steak." This is grammatically correct but sounds unnatural. Consider: "Di sana ada perapian, dan kayu bakar bisa disimpan di teras. Panggangan gas juga bisa ditaruh di sana, buat memanggang steak." (There's a fireplace there, and you can store firewood on the terrace. You can also put the gas grill there, for grilling steaks.)

Generate a new, final, and improved translation in Indonesian:

source_text:
"Tell me about your dream house," Hollis said, smiling.

"Okay," I said, slowly. This was something I didn't talk about too often. "It will have to be off the beaten road, of course. I want it to look like a log cabin, but without the inconveniences of a real log cabin. I found a plan on the Internet, and I bought it. But of course, I want to alter it a little."

"Of course," he said, taking a sip of beer. "

It would be two bedrooms and a study, with a family room. There'd be a kitchen here, with the washroom right off of it." I was looking down at the table, drawing with my finger. "Around back, there'd be a *porte cochere* for the cars, so you could carry groceries right into the kitchen without getting wet. There's a deck off the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'd put it off the family room. That's where the fireplace will be, and you could keep your firewood on the deck. And you could put your gas grill on the deck. For steaks."

Aku ingin tampilannya seperti pondok kayu, tetapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan pondok kayu sungguhan. Aku menemukan rancangannya di Internet, dan aku membelinya. Tapi tentu saja, aku ingin mengubahnya sedikit."

"Tentu," katanya sambil meneguk bir.

Akan ada dua kamar tidur dan ruang kerja, beserta ruang keluarga. Akan ada dapur di sini, dengan kamar mandi tepat di sampingnya. Aku menunduk melihat meja, menggambar dengan jari. "Di bagian belakang, akan ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa membawa belanjaan langsung ke dapur tanpa basah. Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di samping ruang keluarga. Di sanalah perapian akan berada, dan kamu bisa menyimpan kayu bakar di teras. Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak."

The translation of "off the beaten road" as "jauh dari keramaian" is a bit too literal and lacks the evocative quality of the original. The use of "Tentu" as a filler word is also a bit clunky. The translation of "*porte cochere*" is good, but the overall sentence structure feels somewhat formal and less conversational than the English. The final sentence regarding the grill feels slightly awkward.

needs_revision

The translation needs improvement to better capture the informal tone and conversational flow of the original. Here's a breakdown with specific examples:

1. "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari keramaian." could be improved to "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari pusat kota." or "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus di tempat yang terpencil." The current translation is a little too formal. "Pusat kota" (city center) or "terpencil" (remote) would better convey the sense of being away from populated areas.

2. The repetition of "Tentu" ("Of course") feels unnatural. Consider rephrasing: "Tentu saja," katanya sambil meneguk bir. could become "Tentu saja, katanya sambil menyesap bir." or "Dia mengangguk, "Tentu saja.""

3. "Aku ingin tampilannya seperti pondok kayu, tetapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan pondok kayu sungguhan." could be more natural: "Aku ingin rumahnya terlihat seperti pondok kayu, tapi tanpa semua masalah pondok kayu." or "Aku pengen rumahnya kayak kabin kayu, tapi tanpa ribetnya kabin kayu beneran." Using "ribet" (complicated/troublesome) makes it more colloquial.

4. "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat?" could be improved to "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat kan?" Adding "kan?" (right?) makes the sentence more conversational.

5. "Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak." This is a bit awkward. Consider: "Dan kamu bisa taruh pemanggang gas di teras. Biar buat steak." "Taruh" (put) is more colloquial than "meletakkan," and "Biar buat steak" is a more natural way to say "so you can make steak."

2. The repetition of "Tentu" ("Of course") feels unnatural. Consider rephrasing: "Tentu saja," katanya sambil meneguk bir. could become "Tentu saja, katanya sambil menyesap bir." or "Dia mengangguk, "Tentu saja.""

3. "Aku ingin tampilannya seperti pondok kayu, tetapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan pondok kayu sungguhan." could be more natural: "Aku ingin rumahnya terlihat seperti pondok kayu, tapi tanpa semua masalah pondok kayu." or "Aku pengen rumahnya kayak kabin kayu, tapi tanpa ribetnya kabin kayu beneran." Using "ribet" (complicated/troublesome) makes it more colloquial.

4. "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat?" could be improved to "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat kan?" Adding "kan?" (right?) makes the sentence more conversational.

5. "Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak." This is a bit awkward. Consider: "Dan kamu bisa taruh pemanggang gas di teras. Biar buat steak." "Taruh" (put) is more colloquial than "meletakkan," and "Biar buat steak" is a more natural way to say "so you can make steak."

--- NEW TRANSLATION (The Implementation) ---
"Ceritakan dong tentang rumah impianmu," kata Hollis, sambil tersenyum.

"Oke," ujarku, pelan-pelan. Ini bukan sesuatu yang sering aku bicarakan. "Pastilah jauh dari keramaian. Aku pengen rumahnya kayak kabin kayu, tapi tanpa semua ribetnya kabin kayu beneran. Aku nemu gambarnya di internet, terus belinya. Tapi tentu saja, aku mau nambahin sedikit."

"Tentu saja," jawabnya, sambil meneguk bir.

Rumahnya bakal ada dua kamar tidur sama ruang kerja, terus ada ruang keluarga. Ada dapur di sini, terus kamar mandi persis di sebelahnya. Aku menunduk, sambil nggaruk-garuk meja. "Di belakang, bakal ada *porte cochere* buat mobil, biar kamu bisa bawa belanjaan langsung masuk ke dapur tanpa basah. Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat kan? Atau mungkin aku taruh di sisi ruang keluarga. Di situ ada perapian, terus kamu bisa nyimpen kayu bakar di teras. Terus kamu bisa taruh pemanggang gas di teras juga. Buat steak."

--- TASK ---
Did the New Translation successfully implement the changes described in the Original Critique? Respond with only `pass` or `fail`.

source_text:
"Tell me about your dream house," Hollis said, smiling.

"Okay," I said, slowly. This was something I didn't talk about too often. "It will have to be off the beaten road, of course. I want it to look like a log cabin, but without the inconveniences of a real log cabin. I found a plan on the Internet, and I bought it. But of course, I want to alter it a little."

"Of course," he said, taking a sip of beer. "

It would be two bedrooms and a study, with a family room. There'd be a kitchen here, with the washroom right off of it." I was looking down at the table, drawing with my finger. "Around back, there'd be a *porte cochere* for the cars, so you could carry groceries right into the kitchen without getting wet. There's a deck off the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'd put it off the family room. That's where the fireplace will be, and you could keep your firewood on the deck. And you could put your gas grill on the deck. For steaks."

Tapi tentu saja, aku ingin mengubahnya sedikit."

"Tentu," katanya sambil menyesap bir.

Akan ada dua kamar tidur dan ruang kerja, beserta ruang keluarga. Akan ada dapur di sini, dengan kamar mandi tepat di sampingnya. Aku menunduk, menggambar dengan jariku di atas meja. "Di bagian belakang, akan ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa membawa belanjaan langsung ke dapur tanpa basah. Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di sisi ruang keluarga. Di sanalah perapian akan berada, dan kamu bisa menyimpan kayu bakar di teras. Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak."

feedback:
--- ANALYSIS ---
The source text conveys a tone of dry wit and understated skepticism. The narrator is clearly doubtful about the "dream house" narrative, using colloquial language ("off the beaten road") and sarcastic remarks ("without the inconveniences of a real log cabin"). The style is conversational and direct. The meaning is straightforward: the narrator is responding to someone's description of their ideal home with disbelief, highlighting the impracticality of the idea.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally good but lacks the punch and natural flow of the original. The phrase "Tentu saja" is repeated frequently and feels a bit clunky. The use of "menyesap bir" is accurate, but the overall phrasing could be more idiomatic. The translation of "*porte cochere*" as "porte cochere" is acceptable, but it might benefit from a more descriptive phrase if the target audience is not familiar with the term. The repetition of "Tentu saja" diminishes the impact of the dialogue. The sentence structure in some places is a little too literal, leading to less natural-sounding Indonesian.

--- VERDICT ---
needs_revision

The translation needs improvement to better capture the conversational tone and the narrator's skepticism. Here's a breakdown of areas to improve:

1.  **Repetition of "Tentu saja":** Instead of repeating "Tentu saja" after every sentence, try using alternative phrases like "Tentu," "Ya," or simply omitting it where it doesn't add significant meaning. For example, instead of "Tentu saja," katanya sambil menyesap bir, consider "Ya," katanya sambil menyesap bir, or simply " katanya sambil menyesap bir."
2.  **"Porte Cochere":** While "porte cochere" is understandable, consider a more descriptive phrase that conveys the meaning. Something like "tempat parkir tertutup" (covered parking space) or "area parkir yang terlindung" (sheltered parking area) might sound more natural. If the context allows, a brief explanation of the term could be included in the first mention.
3.  **Sentence Structure:** Some sentences are too literal and sound awkward in Indonesian. For example, "Akan ada dua kamar tidur dan ruang kerja, dengan ruang keluarga" could be rephrased as "Rumahnya akan memiliki dua kamar tidur, ruang kerja, dan ruang keluarga."
4.  **Overall Flow:** The translation lacks a certain rhythm. Consider rearranging phrases and clauses to create a more natural flow. For instance, the description of the kitchen and washroom could be combined for a smoother read.
5.  **Specificity of Descriptors:** Consider adding slightly more specific descriptors. Instead of just "di luar jalur umum", perhaps "di daerah yang agak terpencil" (in a somewhat remote area) to better reflect the implied meaning.

Untuk steak."

Start again from scratch, keeping the feedback in mind.

--- CONTEXT ---
Text type: fictional text, novel excerpt
Source Language: English
Target Language: Indonesian

--- SOURCE TEXT ---
"Tell me about your dream house," Hollis said, smiling.

"Okay," I said, slowly. This was something I didn't talk about too often. "It will have to be off the beaten road, of course. I want it to look like a log cabin, but without the inconveniences of a real log cabin. I found a plan on the Internet, and I bought it. But of course, I want to alter it a little."

"Of course," he said, taking a sip of beer. "

It would be two bedrooms and a study, with a family room. There'd be a kitchen here, with the washroom right off of it." I was looking down at the table, drawing with my finger. "Around back, there'd be a *porte cochere* for the cars, so you could carry groceries right into the kitchen without getting wet. There's a deck off the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'd put it off the family room. That's where the fireplace will be, and you could keep your firewood on the deck. And you could put your gas grill on the deck. For steaks."

--- EDITOR'S FEEDBACK ---
--- ANALYSIS ---
The source text conveys a tone of dry wit and understated skepticism. The narrator is clearly doubtful about the "dream house" narrative, using colloquial language ("off the beaten road") and sarcastic remarks ("without the inconveniences of a real log cabin"). The style is conversational and direct. The meaning is straightforward: the narrator is responding to someone's description of their ideal home with disbelief, highlighting the impracticality of the idea.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally good but lacks the punch and natural flow of the original. The phrase "Tentu saja" is repeated frequently and feels a bit clunky. The use of "menyesap bir" is accurate, but the overall phrasing could be more idiomatic. The translation of "*porte cochere*" as "porte cochere" is acceptable, but it might benefit from a more descriptive phrase if the target audience is not familiar with the term. The repetition of "Tentu saja" diminishes the impact of the dialogue. The sentence structure in some places is a little too literal, leading to less natural-sounding Indonesian.

--- VERDICT ---
needs_revision

The translation needs improvement to better capture the conversational tone and the narrator's skepticism. Here's a breakdown of areas to improve:

1.  **Repetition of "Tentu saja":** Instead of repeating "Tentu saja" after every sentence, try using alternative phrases like "Tentu," "Ya," or simply omitting it where it doesn't add significant meaning. For example, instead of "Tentu saja," katanya sambil menyesap bir, consider "Ya," katanya sambil menyesap bir, or simply " katanya sambil menyesap bir."
2.  **"Porte Cochere":** While "porte cochere" is understandable, consider a more descriptive phrase that conveys the meaning. Something like "tempat parkir tertutup" (covered parking space) or "area parkir yang terlindung" (sheltered parking area) might sound more natural. If the context allows, a brief explanation of the term could be included in the first mention.
3.  **Sentence Structure:** Some sentences are too literal and sound awkward in Indonesian. For example, "Akan ada dua kamar tidur dan ruang kerja, dengan ruang keluarga" could be rephrased as "Rumahnya akan memiliki dua kamar tidur, ruang kerja, dan ruang keluarga."
4.  **Overall Flow:** The translation lacks a certain rhythm. Consider rearranging phrases and clauses to create a more natural flow. For instance, the description of the kitchen and washroom could be combined for a smoother read.
5.  **Specificity of Descriptors:** Consider adding slightly more specific descriptors. Instead of just "di luar jalur umum", perhaps "di daerah yang agak terpencil" (in a somewhat remote area) to better reflect the implied meaning.

--- FINAL TASK ---
Generate a new, final, and improved translation in Indonesian:

feedback:
--- ANALYSIS ---
The source text uses informal language ("Tell me...", "Okay," "Of course") and a slightly cynical, world-weary tone. The character is clearly skeptical and not easily convinced. The phrasing is direct and conversational, reflecting a narrative style common in detective or mystery fiction. The repetition of "of course" emphasizes the character's disbelief or mild exasperation. The use of the word "porte cochere" adds a touch of detail and realism.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally accurate but lacks the punch and natural flow of the original. The phrase "Tentu saja" is used repeatedly, which, while correct, becomes somewhat monotonous. The translation tends to be overly formal in places, losing some of the casualness present in the English.  For example, "rumah impianmu" is a bit stiff. The translation of "*porte cochere*" is accurate but might benefit from a more natural Indonesian equivalent if one exists and maintains the intended meaning. The overall sentence structure is often a bit lengthy and could be broken down for better readability.

--- VERDICT ---
needs_revision

The translation needs revision to better capture the informal tone and conversational style of the original. Here's a breakdown of specific areas for improvement:

1. "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari keramaian." - This is grammatically correct but sounds a bit formal. Consider: "Tentu saja, rumahnya harus jauh dari hiruk pikuk." (Of course, the house has to be far from the hustle and bustle.)  Or, even more casually: "Ya, rumahnya harus jauh dari tengah kota, tentu saja." (Yeah, the house has to be far from the city center, of course.)

2. "Aku ingin tampilannya seperti pondok kayu, tapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan pondok kayu sungguhan." - This is a bit clunky. "Aku ingin rumahnya terlihat seperti pondok kayu, tapi tanpa semua masalah pondok kayu biasa." (I want the house to look like a log cabin, but without all the usual log cabin problems.)

3. "Di bagian belakang, akan ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa membawa belanjaan langsung ke dapur tanpa basah kuyup." -  The phrase "tanpa basah kuyup" is a bit dramatic and slightly unnatural in this context. Consider: "Di belakang, ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa langsung masuk dapur dengan barang belanjaan, tanpa kena hujan." (In the back, there's a porte cochere for the car, so you can go straight into the kitchen with groceries, without getting wet from the rain.)  If a more common Indonesian term exists for a porte cochere, use that.

4. "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di sisi ruang keluarga." - The "lihat?" feels a bit tacked on and unnatural. It’s better to simply state the alternative.  "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di sisi ruang keluarga." (There's a terrace on the right side of the kitchen, or maybe I'll place it on the side of the living room.)

5. Repetition of "Tentu" - While accurate, it makes the Indonesian sound a bit repetitive. Vary the phrasing. For example, instead of "Tentu saja," use "Ya," "Tentu," or omit it entirely in some instances.

The source text uses informal language ("Tell me...", "Okay," "Of course") and a slightly cynical, world-weary tone. The character is clearly skeptical and not easily convinced. The phrasing is direct and conversational, reflecting a narrative style common in detective or mystery fiction. The repetition of "of course" emphasizes the character's disbelief or mild exasperation. The use of the word "porte cochere" adds a touch of detail and realism.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally accurate but lacks the punch and natural flow of the original. The phrase "Tentu saja" is used repeatedly, which, while correct, becomes somewhat monotonous. The translation tends to be overly formal in places, losing some of the casualness present in the English.  For example, "rumah impianmu" is a bit stiff. The translation of "*porte cochere*" is accurate but might benefit from a more natural Indonesian equivalent if one exists and maintains the intended meaning. The overall sentence structure is often a bit lengthy and could be broken down for better readability.

needs_revision

The translation needs revision to better capture the informal tone and conversational style of the original. Here's a breakdown of specific areas for improvement:

(Of course, the house has to be far from the hustle and bustle.)  Or, even more casually: "Ya, rumahnya harus jauh dari tengah kota, tentu saja." (Yeah, the house has to be far from the city center, of course.)

2. "Aku ingin tampilannya seperti pondok kayu, tapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan pondok kayu sungguhan." - This is a bit clunky. "Aku ingin rumahnya terlihat seperti pondok kayu, tapi tanpa semua masalah pondok kayu biasa." (I want the house to look like a log cabin, but without all the usual log cabin problems.)

3. "Di bagian belakang, akan ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa membawa belanjaan langsung ke dapur tanpa basah kuyup." -  The phrase "tanpa basah kuyup" is a bit dramatic and slightly unnatural in this context. Consider: "Di belakang, ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa langsung masuk dapur dengan barang belanjaan, tanpa kena hujan." (In the back, there's a porte cochere for the car, so you can go straight into the kitchen with groceries, without getting wet from the rain.)  If a more common Indonesian term exists for a porte cochere, use that.

4. "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, lihat? Atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di sisi ruang keluarga." - The "lihat?" feels a bit tacked on and unnatural. It’s better to simply state the alternative.  "Ada teras di sisi kanan dapur, atau mungkin aku akan menempatkannya di sisi ruang keluarga." (There's a terrace on the right side of the kitchen, or maybe I'll place it on the side of the living room.)

5. Repetition of "Tentu" - While accurate, it makes the Indonesian sound a bit repetitive. Vary the phrasing. For example, instead of "Tentu saja," use "Ya," "Tentu," or omit it entirely in some instances.

The meaning is straightforward: the narrator is responding to a statement about a dream house by expressing disbelief and offering a slightly sarcastic and detailed counterpoint.

--- EVALUATION ---
The translation is generally good, but some phrases could be improved to better capture the nuances of the original. The use of "Baiklah" is a bit too formal in this context; "Oke" or "Ya" would be more natural. The phrase "rumah impianmu" is a direct translation of "your dream house" and lacks the subtle sarcastic tone of the original.  The translation is accurate but lacks the conversational flow and slightly cynical tone present in the English. The repetition of "Tentu saja" feels a little unnatural and can be refined. The use of "sambil menyesap bir" is a bit clunky and could be phrased more elegantly.

needs_revision

1.  **"Ceritakan tentang rumah impianmu," Hollis berkata, sambil tersenyum.**  Replace "rumah impianmu" with a more natural phrase that conveys the same meaning with a bit more casualness, such as "rumah idealmu" or even just "rumah impian."  Better yet, consider "rumah yang kamu inginkan," which translates to "the house you want". This is more conversational.

2.  **"Oke," jawabku, perlahan. Ini adalah sesuatu yang jarang sekali saya bicarakan.**  Instead of "Baiklah," use "Oke" or "Ya". The phrase "Ini adalah sesuatu yang jarang sekali saya bicarakan" is a bit wordy; consider "Ini bukan sesuatu yang sering aku bicarakan" (This isn't something I often talk about).

3.  **"Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari keramaian. Saya ingin tampilannya seperti pondok kayu, tetapi tanpa ketidaknyamanan pondok kayu yang sebenarnya."**  The repetition of "Tentu saja" is unnecessary.  Rephrase to something like: "Tentu saja, rumah itu harus jauh dari keramaian. Aku menginginkan tampilannya seperti pondok kayu, tetapi tanpa semua ketidaknyamanan pondok kayu yang sebenarnya."

Try something like: "Di bagian belakang, ada *porte cochere* untuk mobil, jadi kamu bisa langsung membawa belanjaan ke dapur tanpa kena hujan." This is more natural and avoids the slightly formal tone.

5.  **"Dan Anda bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk steak."** This sentence is grammatically correct, but it could be more concise. "Dan kamu bisa meletakkan pemanggang gas di teras. Untuk memanggang steak." is a better option.

Rumahnya akan terdiri dari dua kamar tidur dan ruang kerja, dengan ruang keluarga. Ada dapur di sana, dengan wastafel tepat di sebelahnya. Aku menunduk, menggambar di meja dengan jari. source_text:
"Tell me about your dream house," Hollis said, smiling.

"Okay," I said, slowly. This was something I didn't talk about too often. "It will have to be off the beaten road, of course. I want it to look like a log cabin, but without the inconveniences of a real log cabin. I found a plan on the Internet, and I bought it. But of course, I want to alter it a little."

"Of course," he said, taking a sip of beer. "

It would be two bedrooms and a study, with a family room. There'd be a kitchen here, with the washroom right off of it." I was looking down at the table, drawing with my finger. "Around back, there'd be a *porte cochere* for the cars, so you could carry groceries right into the kitchen without getting wet. There's a deck off the right side of the kitchen, see? Or maybe I'd put it off the family room. That's where the fireplace will be, and you could keep your firewood on the deck. And you could put your gas grill on the deck. For steaks."
